Title:
Identification and distribution of Cytospora canker disease
of Malus spp. in Xinjiang, China
Keywords:
Cytospora spp., distribution, Malus spp., morphology,
phylogeny
Abstract:
Apple canker caused by Cytospora is poses a serious threat
to the apple industry and negatively impacts economic and social
development of farmers living in Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous (XJUA)
RegionÂ—one of the most important apple-producing areas in China. However,
little is known about the distribution and characteristics of Cytospora
species associated with Malus spp. In this study, 134 isolates were
obtained from 86 symptomatic samples collected from 8 Prefecture in XJUA
Region between 2010 and 2017. We identified 15 Cytospora species using
morphological characteristics combined with multilocus phylogenetic
analyses of the ITS region, LSU, RPB2, TEF1, and ACT1 genes.
Pathogenicity tests confirmed that these isolates caused necrotic
lesions on stems of M. sieversii and/or M. domestica. This is the first
report of two novel species causing apple canker - Cytospora
hippophaopsis on M. sieversii and C. shawanensis on M. domestica. This
is also the first report worldwide of apple canker associated with C.
erumpens on M. sieversii and M. domestica, of C. cincta and C. schulzeri
on M. sieversii. Cytospora leucostoma and C. mali on M. domestica are
reported for the first time in XJUA Region. Twenty new distribution
areas were identified for nine Cytospora species in XJUA Region.
Cytospora carbonacea, C. cincta, C. chrysosperma, C. leucosperma, C.
nivea, C. parakantschavelii, C. parasitica, C. pruinopsis, C.
salicicola, and C. schulzeri have been recorded in XJUA Region. This
study represents the first attempt to clarify Cytospora species
associated with canker and dieback symptoms of Malus spp. in XJUA
Region, China.
